CONGRATS: J.F. Drake Middle School received a special plaque commemorating its outstanding contribution to Alabama‚Äôs recent bicentennial celebration!

Between March 3, 2017, and Dec. 14, 2019, every county, more than 200 local community committees and dozens of organizations throughout the state participated in Alabama‚Äôs bicentennial commemoration. They undertook hundreds of projects and activities over the three-year celebration. From those, the Alabama Bicentennial Commission selected 21 projects to receive legacy awards and 41 to receive commendations. All made a significant and/or lasting contribution to the state‚Äôs commemoration.

The specially made bronze plaque recognizes the efforts of DMS educators for hosting ‚ÄúRemembering the Great War,‚Äù a traveling exhibit on Alabama and World War One. At the time of the exhibition a team of 6th grade students researched various aspects of the war and were on hand to offer additional information to the public through panel discussions, artifacts and themes of the exhibit.

The plaque will be displayed within the new DMS campus.

During the week of August 24-28 Auburn City Schools reported 9 confirmed cases of COVID-19 to the Alabama Department of Public Health. Due to the potential of close contact exposure at school, 89 students must complete the required 14 day quarantine.
As students and teachers continue to practice preventative measures through the use of facial coverings, social distancing, and proper hand hygiene at school, we ask that parents and guardians remain the first line of defense with daily screenings of symptoms related to COVID-19. Students with symptoms of illness should stay home and will be excused from school. In the circumstance of one family member being ill or having a positive or pending COVID-19 test, all other members of the household must be quarantined and follow the direction of healthcare officials.
We are thankful for the collective effort from all community stakeholders to keep our schools safe.

AUGUST 23 UPDATE: With the commitment and hard work of students, staff and families, we had a successful and productive second week of school. During the week of August 17-21, Auburn City Schools reported five cases of COVID-19 to the Alabama Department of Public Health. Due to the potential of close contact exposure at school, 30 students must complete the required 14 day quarantine. Our continued success requires a daily screening for symptoms related to the Coronavirus such as fever, cough, runny nose, sinus congestion, trouble breathing, pressure in chest, abdominal pain, stomach ache, diarrhea or vomiting, body aches, or new loss of taste or smell. Students with symptoms of illness will be excused from school.

Students and teachers are to be commended for their use of facial covering, social distancing, and hand hygiene. With much appreciation for the partnership of all stakeholders, Auburn City Schools extends gratitude for the collective effort of our school community.

‚Ä¢

‚Ä¢
Following Governor Kay Ivey‚Äôs State of Emergency to close schools for an extended period, the time of closure was modified to three weeks and the expectation is to reopen schools on Monday April 6th. Therefore, the reopening of schools will be considered with consultation from the Alabama Department of Public Health.
‚Ä¢
ACS will continue to share communications routinely via social media (Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram), the system website (www.auburnschools.org) and our mass-notification system, which allows ACS to communicate to all students, staff, and parents via text, email, and phone calls.
‚Ä¢
We encourage parents to follow their child‚Äôs teacher webpage for age-appropriate learning resources as well as checking their school‚Äôs webpage for additional listings of learning opportunities to utilize at home.
‚Ä¢
We are also pleased to be partnering with The Auburn Dream Center, community partners, and area agencies to formulate plans to efficiently provide for our food-insecure students.

Cristen Herring
Superintendent
Auburn City Schools

- 2‚Ä¢ Recognize and honor the contributions of our local veterans through the recording of the oral histories and the providing of copies to the public via this website and donation to the Library of Congress Veterans History Project (copies also given to the veterans).
- 3‚Ä¢ Develop a positive relationship with the community through service-learning as the students learn how to create and publish history for a general audience.
